div.p: THE QUEENS Cabinet Newly Opened: And the Art of Phyſick diſcovered; Wherein you ſhall finde diverſe Rare Receipts; both of Phyſick and of Chyrurgery: Very good and very profitable for all ſorts of Men, Women, and Children. Together with ſeverall Medicines, for to prevent, and for to cure the moſt Peſtilent Diſeaſes that Raineth in any Cattel, and that with ſmall Coſt and Charges.
By Mr. John Ponteus.
London, Printed for Richard Burton, at the Horſe ſhoe in Smith-field, 1662.

div.head: The firſt Remedy is againſt the riſing of the Mother.
div.p: TAke a quart of the ſtrongeſt and the ſtaleſt bear you can get, and nine tops of Roſemary, and as much large Mace as will weigh down nine pence, and a hand full of inward bark of night-ſhad, boile all theſe together in a Copper skellet till it comes to a pint, then ſtrain it, and drink three ſpoonfuls one after another, juſt as the fit begins to come upon you, and you ſhall finde preſent remedy.

div.head: For a burning, or ſcalding, or any green wound.
div.p:
Take Mutten ſuet, and ſheeps dung, and the inward bark of Elder: boile them together,
and then ſtrain it, and then anoint the place grieved therewith, and it ſhall heal it without any ſcar.

div.head: For any ſoare new or old.
div.p: Take the inward bark of an Aſh-tree, and then boile it well in a quart of ſpring water; then bath any ſore with it, three or foure times every morning & evening, and then anoint it with freſh butter and flower of Brimſtone, well mixed together, and you ſhall ſee a ſpeedy cure.

div.head: For all aches and lame members.
div.p: Take Rye, and Roſemary, two handfuls, put them into ſallet oyle and malmſie, of each one quart, let them boile half an houre together, then let the place greived, be anointed therewith againſt the fire: being firſt chaffed with a cloath very well, and after nointing, wrap it up in a Lambs skin, the woolle ſide inward, doe this to bed-ward, for the ſpace of three weeks together, this cured a man that could neither ſtand nor goe, probatum.

div.head: For the Falling Sickneſs.
div.p: Take the skull of a man or woman, waſh it purely clean, then dry it in the Oven, after your bread be drawn, beat it to fine powder, then boile it in poſſet drink, then let the party drink thereof Morning and Evening, or as oft as need requireth, it is an approved remedy.

div.head: For a Tetter or Ring-worm,
div.p: Take half an ounce of white Copperis, deſolved in a pint of ſpring water, then waſh the Tetter therewith, and it will kill all Tetters and Ring-worms.

div.head: For the Rickets.
div.p: Take a handful of the inward bark of Tammaras, and lay it in ſteep in a pint of Whitewine two or three daies, and let the diſeaſed Child drink now and then two ſpoonfuls of it at a time, and it will ſpeedily cure it.

div.head: For the Pain of the Back.
div.p: Take Sage, Roſemary, Cammomil of each of them a handful; then ſtamp them together, and frie them with the Oyl of Swallows, and then annoint your back therewith warm.

div.head: For ſore eyes.
div.p: Take Eyebright-water, and waſh your eyes therewith morning and evening; it will both heal the eyes and ſtrengthen the ſight.

div.head: For the Cramp.
div.p: Take your fore-finger and rub it between your toes when you go to bed, then ſmell to your finger, it will take away the Cramp, and cure the Palſie.

div.head: For the Rhume in the Eyes.
div.p: Take Marigold-water and waſh your eyes therewith morning and evening; it cureth the diſeaſes in the eyes, and it will take away the pain of the head.

div.head: For a Quincy or ſwelling in the Throat.
div.p: Take a needleful of white ſilk, and dip it in the blood of a Mouſe, and let the party ſwallow it down, and it will ſpeedily cure it.

div.head: For the paine or noiſe in your Eares.
div.p: Firſt waſh your eares with White-Wine, then take a good handful of Earth-worms, and frie them with. Gooſe-greace, then ſtraine it, and drop two dropes into each eare when it is hot; and it will take away the paine and noiſe thereof.

div.head: For the Itch.
div.p: Take four ounces of unſalted Butter: take Brimſtone, Cloves, Pepper, and Ginger, of each of them a pennyworth, then mix them together, and beat them to fine powder, and then anoint your joints againſt the fire, and in three times doing ſo it will cure you.

div.head: For to remove a Diſeaſe from the ſtomack.
div.p: Take a quarter of a pint of ſack, and a pennyworth of fine Treacle, then mix them together, and drink it blood warm going to bed, and in twice taking of it will cure you.

div.head: For a burning Feaver.
div.p: Take two handfuls of Redmints, boile them in a quart of ſpring water, till it comes to a pint; and then ſtrain it; and put thereto four or five ſpoonfuls of white wine Vinegar, and as much Hony, boil it till it comes to a ſyrrup, take of Endive, ſuckary, of each two handfuls, boile it in a quart of ſpring water, till half be conſumed, take two ſpoonfulls of this, and more of the ſirrup, in the morning faſting, and at any other time when you pleaſe, and the Feaver ſhall leave you, and you will recover; probat.

div.head: For an Ague.
div.p:
Take all the Urine the party maketh at one time, and put ſome flower into it, and knead it: and make thereof a Cake
and bake it; and when it is baked, give it to the dog of the houſe, juſt as the fit begins to come upon you, doe ſo two or three times, and the party will be well, and the dog ſick.

div.head: For the Gout.
div.p: Take a handful of Mugwort ſtamped, and boyled in a pint of the beſt ſallet Oile, till the juice be conſumed, then ſtraine it, and it will make an Ointment that ſhall give ſpeedy eaſe to the Gout, probat.

div.head: For a ſore or any green wound.
div.p: Take the coles of a Burtch tree beaten to fine powder, and put it into an wound or ſore, heales it not only perfectly, but ſpeedily.

div.head: For the ſpleen.
div.p: Take the Rine of an Aſh Tree, boyled in a quart of White Wine, then drink it ſix or ſeven mornings faſting together, will cure you.

div.head: For a Stich.
div.p: Take oyle of Dil, oyle of Capers, oyle of Swallowes, of each one ounce; then mix them together, and then anoint your ſide againſt the fire when the pain is upon you; and it will take away the pain thereof.

div.head: For the Yellow Jaundies.
div.p: Take a handfull of the inward barke of a Barbary tree and Gooſe dung that feeds on graſſe, and waſh the white of it, and put thereto a little Saffron; ſteepe them in Ale, and let the Patient drink it in the morning faſting; and it is a preſent remedy.

div.head: For the Scurvey.
div.p: Chop ſmall the knotted place of a Pine tree, and boyle it well in a quart of Ale or Beere, that the ſteem may come out; and drink of it as often as you pleaſe: and it will cure the Scurvey.

div.head: For the Black Jaundies.
div.p: Take of Herbe Ambroſe, Bettony, Mugworth, of each a handfull; three or foure Dock roots, clean pickt, waſht and ſcraped, ſtampe all theſe in a Morter till they be indifferent ſmall: Then take Spicknard, Turmarick, and gallingall, of each a handfull; Stamp them in a Morter likewiſe; then mix them together and put them into a clean cloath by themſelves, and tye them faſt with ſtrings, and then hange them in two gallands of good Ale newly ready to be tunned up, and after three or foure dayes, drink a good draught thereof every morning next your heart, & faſt after it three hours, and do ſo the like when you go to bed; and you ſhall finde preſent remedy, probat.

div.head: For a Conſumption.
div.p:
Take three Sheeps hearts, ſlit them and take out the ſtrings and blood, and lay them in water to ſoak a night and a day, then waſh them clean and put them into a Pipkin, lay in the bottom of the Pipkin ſtalkes of Roſemary in the manner of a Gridiron, then lay the hearts on
them, every heart being ſtuck with three Cloves, and half a quarter of Sugar being put into every heart; then ſtop up the pipkin very cloſe with paſte, and put it into an oven with houſhold-bread; and when you think it is ſufficiently ſtewed take out the pipkin again; then every morning and evening take a ſpoonful of this Syrrup, and it will cure you.

div.head: A moſt excellent Water for a Conſumption.
div.p: Take Roſewater, and Muſcadine, of each three pints, of new Milk a pottle, of groſſe Pepper one ounce, of Cinnamon one ounce, of ſliced bread a penny-loaf, the yolkes of three new laid Eggs, of Sugar one pound; diſtil all theſe as long as any water will come; take of this water with a little beaten Pepper a draught faſting, and you ſhall find it do you very much good. Probat.

div.head: For the Cough of the Lungs.
div.p: Take Coltsfoot, Bettony, Burnet and red Roſe leaves, of each a handful; of Comfrey roots, ſcraped and ſliced two handfuls; boyl all theſe in a gallon of ſpring-water, till it comes to a pottle; then ſtrain it, and ſet it over the fire again; then take a pound of double reſined Sugar, and put into it, and let it boyl over a ſoft fire about a quarter of an hour; then take it off, and put it into ſome glaſſe, and ſtop it up cloſe, and then drink ſix ſpoonfuls morning and evening, and at four in the afternoon; it is an approved Remedy.

div.head: For to take away the redneſſe of the face.
div.p: Take the roots of white Lillies, and boile them in a quart of Spring-water, and waſh your face in the ſaid water, and it will take away the redneſſe thereof.

div.head: For Hearing.
div.p: Take four drops of the juice of Bettony, and warm it in a ſauſar, then drop it into each ear when you goe to bed, then ſtop them up with black wooll, and it will recover your hearing.

div.head: For to take away a Wen.
div.p: Take unſlacked Lime beaten to fine powder, then mixed with black Sope, then anoint the Wen therewith, and it will take it away.

div.head: For the paine at the Heart or Stomach.
div.p: Take four graines of Maſtick at evening going to bed, and it will take away the paine thereof.

div.head: For a Sinew ſtrain'd.
div.p: Take Nerve oile, Pompillion, and Oyle of Exeter, of each two penniworth, then mix them together, and warm it in a ſaucer, then anoint the joint therewith, and bind it up cloſe, and it cureth.

div.head: For the taking away Warts.
div.p: Take Figtree-leaves and rub your Warts therewith, and bury the ſaid leaves in the ground, and the Warts will conſume away as the leaves do rot.

div.head: For Convulſion fits.
div.p: Take black Cherry-water, and the Syrrup of Violets, of each two peny worth, then mix them together; and take three or foure ſpoonfuls of it at a time, juſt as the fit begins to come upon you, and you ſhall finde preſent remedy, probatum.

div.head: For the Cough or ſtopping of the breath.
div.p: Take the ſyrrup of Hyſop, the ſyrrup of Lickariſh, the ſyrrup of maiden haire, of each an ounce, and take thereof every morning a ſpoonfull or two.

div.head: For the Head-ache.
div.p: Take a handfull of Speremint, and ſhred it ſmal, then grate ſome Nut-mege into it, with ſome Roſe-water, and binde it cloſe to your fore-head, and it will take away the pain thereof.

div.head: For the Wormes in Children
div.p: Take two ounces of Purſlain-ſeed, and boil it in a pint of white Wine; then give it the Childe faſting three mornings together, and it will kill the Worms.

div.head: For a ſore Throat.
div.p: Take Collumbine and Cinquefoil, then ſtamp and boil them together, and ſtrain them into Milk, and drink it very warm.

div.head: For the pain in the Head.
div.p: Take Aloes boyled well with the juyce of Coleworts, and made into pills, a ſcruple being taken at a time at night going to bed, doth moſt gallantly eaſe the head, and take away the pain thereof.

div.head: For the Tooth-ach.
div.p: Take two handfuls of Wood bettony, and then boyl it in a pint of white Wine till half be conſumed, then take a ſpoonful of it, and keep it in your mouth, do ſo two or three times together, and if there be any worms in them they die, and it ſhall keep the Teeth from all pain.

div.head: For to draw a Thorn out of the Fleſh.
div.p: Take a handfull of Bettony, bruiſe it in a Morter, then mixt it with Black ſoap, and it will draw out any thing that is gotten deep into the fleſh.

div.head: For a Plurifie.
div.p: Take two ounces of Dialthea, and annoint the grieved place therewith; then take Cummin-ſeed beaten to fine powder, and ſtrew it upon the annointed place, then heat a Colewort leaf very hot upon coals; and bind it to the place very faſt, and you ſhall find a preſent cure.

div.head: For to cure a Dropſie.
div.p: Take the roots of Elder, and boyl them in a gallon of ſpring water till it comes to a pottle, and drink it as common drink, and it will ſpeedily cure you.

div.head: For a Canker in the Mouth.
div.p: Take the juyce of Plantain leaves, Vinegar and water of Roſes, and waſh your mouth therewith.

div.head: For ſpitting of Bloud.
div.p: Take Smallage and Mints, Rue and Betony, and boyl them in good milk, and ſup it warm.

div.head: For a Pin and Web in the eye.
div.p: Take the fine powder of Licorice blown through a quill into the eyes; it will take out the Pin or Web thereof.

div.head: For a ſcald Head.
div.p: Take two handfuls of Harrife and ſtamp it a little; then let it ſoak in a quart of ſpring water twenty foure hours; then waſh your head therewith, or any ſcabby place with it, and it will quickly heal it.

div.head: For the Wormes in Children.
div.p: Take the Gall of an Oxe, as much flower of Lupines as will thicken it, and make a plaiſter thereof, and lay it to the navel of the belly; it will kill the Wormes.

div.head: For to ſtop a Looſeneſs.
div.p: Make Pap of Bean-flower, and put thereto powder of Cinnamon,

div.head: For to stay the bloudy Flux.
div.p: Take Pigeons dung ſtamped with white Wine Vinegar, and applied plaiſter-wiſe to the navel of the belly ſtoppeth all Fluxes.

div.head: For the Plague in the guts in Horſes.
div.p: TAke of Cullenbine roots and leaves, in all a good handful, as much Wormwood, and as much Rue; waſh them well, and then bruiſe them in a morter, and then boyl them in a quart of Ale well; and then ſtrain them, and add to the liquor half a pound of ſweet butter; then, being but lukewarm, give it the Horſe to drink; or Diapenthe in a pint of Muſcadine.

div.head: For the ſleeping Evil.
div.p: Firſt keep him much waking, and twice in one week give him as much Soap in the nature of a pill as a Ducks egg, and then after give him a little new milk and honey, which is a preſent cure.

div.head: For the Scratches.
div.p:
Take a pint of Train oyl, and white bread beaten to powder, then mix them together,
and annoint the Horſes legs there with, and chafe it in well, it will bring their legs to be ſmall, and dry up the humours.

div.head: For to make a Horſe ſtaile or piſs.
div.p: Give him ſome Caſtle-ſoap ſliced thin in a pint of white Wine, and he will preſently piſs.

div.head: For the Glaunders.
div.p: Take of Auris figmentum two drachms, of Tuſſilaginis made into powder as much, then mix them together with Turpentine till they be like paſte; make thereof little cakes; and dry them before the fire, then take a chafing-diſh of coals, and laying one or two of the cakes thereon, over them with a tunnel, and then the ſmoak riſing, put the tunnel in the Horſes noſtrils, and let the ſmoak go up into his head, which done, ride the Horſe till he ſweat; do thus every morning before he be watered, till the running of his noſtrils ceaſe, and the kernels under his chaps wear away.

div.head: For the foundring of his body.
div.p:
Firſt give him wholeſome ſtrong meat,
〈◊〉 bread of clean beans, and warm drink; and
for two or three mornings together give him a quart of Ale brewed with Pepper and Cinnamon, and one ounce of London Treacle, and it will cure him.

div.head: For Bots and Wormes of all ſorts.
div.p: Take Savory leaves chopt, and mix them with Honey and butter, and make two or three balls thereof, and make the Horſe ſwallow them down, and it will cure him.

div.head: Of the pain of the Kidneys or the Stone.
div.p: Take a handful of Ma • denhair, and ſte • p it all night in a quart of ſtrong Ale, and give it the Horſe to drink every morning till he be well, this will break any ſtone whatſoever in a Horſe.

div.head: For the gravelling of a horſe in the foot.
div.p: Cut the hoof till you can find the ſore, then take one ounce of Virgins wax, one quarter of an ounce of Rozen, as much Dear Suet, half an ounce of Bores Greaſe, one head of Semgreen, bruiſe all theſe in a Morter, and ſet it over the fire till it be melted, then apply it to the horſe foot, ſpare not to travaile him, for it ſhall heal him.

div.head: For the Farcy or by ſome called the Farcion in a horſe.
div.p: The farcy cometh of the great abundance of blood, therefore you muſt let him blood on both ſides of the Neck, a hand breadth from the head, then take a gallon of fair water, and put thereto a handfull of ſalt, three handfuls of Mallows, two handfuls of Rew, one pound of hempſeed, bruſe all in a morter, then ſeeth them till the husk be wafted, and give it him to drink, then to the outward ſore apply one once of the oyle of Terpentine, one ounce of the oyle of Petre chafe it well in, and it cureth.

div.head: For a Canker in the Mouth.
div.p: Take the inward Bark of an Elder Tree, Sage and Woodbine leaves, chop them ſmal, and boyle them in White wine vineger, and put therein a good quantity of Allum and Honey, then take a linnen Cloath and tie it upon a ſtick, and waſh his Mouth, Tongue, and Root, with the water, twice or thrice a day, and it will be whole ſpeedily.

div.head: For wind-galls.
div.p: The cure is to prick them, and to let out the Gelly, and then dry up the ſore with a plaſter of pitch.

div.head: To draw out a Stub or a Thorne.
div.p: Take a handful of Bettony, bruiſe it in a morter with black ſoape, and lay it to the ſore, and it will draw out the Splint, Iron, Thorne or Stub.

div.head: For the Murrain in Cows, Oxen, or ſuch Cattle.
div.p: Thoſe that are infected, firſt cut off the tip of the Eare, then take the leaves of Bares-foot dried and beaten to pouder, as much as will lye on a ſhilling, and a quart of milk, brew it together, and ſo drench therewith blood-warm.

div.head: To prevent the Murrain.
div.p: Run a Bodkin through the double skin that hangeth at the breaſt of the beaſt, put therein a root of bares-foot, and let it abide.

div.head: For Piſſing of Blood.
div.p: Take two handfuls of Shephards purſe, and boyle it in a quart of Redwine, and then ſtrain it, and put into it a little Cinnamon, and ſo give it the beaſt to drink lukewarme, and it will ſpeedily cure it.

div.head: For to cure any ſwelling in a Beaſt whatſoever.
div.p: If your beaſt have any outward ſwelling bath it with ſalle • oyle and vineger exceeding hot, and it will aſſwage it, but if the ſwelling be inward, then boile round Ariſtolochia in his water:

argument.p: Theſe Receipts have been peruſed and approved of by divers people in the City of London, and are Printed for the good and benefit of the Kingdome.
